title: FACTR: Force-Attending Curriculum Training for Contact-Rich Policy Learning
author: Jason Jingzhou Liu (Carnegie Mellon University), Yulong Li (Carnegie Mellon University), Kenneth Shaw (Carnegie Mellon University), Tony Tao (Carnegie Mellon University), Ruslan Salakhutdinov (Carnegie Mellon University), Deepak Pathak (Carnegie Mellon University)
relevance_why: The approach proposed in this paper enhances policy learning in robotic manipulation tasks, which could inform methodologies for developing audio-visual integration in future generative models, relevant to multimodal research.
background: The paper focuses on improving robot performance in tasks requiring force feedback through a new training method which emphasizes force usage over visual information.
contribution: FACTR introduces a force-attending curriculum training method that helps robots improve their performance in contact-rich tasks, achieving significant improvements in generalization to novel objects.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods primarily utilized visual information for policy learning, often leading to poor generalization when faced with novel objects.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves upon baseline approaches by incorporating force feedback into the training process, allowing the robot to flexibly adapt to various tasks.

key_innovation: The innovative aspect of FACTR is its dynamically adjusting curriculum that begins with high levels of visual corruption, encouraging the model to leverage force data initially.
real_world_impact: This research could advance the development of more capable robots for tasks involving physical interaction, which could lead to safer and more efficient automation in various industries.
limitations: The authors note that the precision of external joint torque sensors is a limitation that can affect fine manipulation tasks.

new_terms.force feedback: **Force feedback** refers to the transmission of force information back to the operator or system to inform control decisions during robotic tasks, enhancing the interaction with the physical environment.
new_terms.curriculum training: **Curriculum training** is a training approach that gradually increases the complexity of tasks presented to the learning model, allowing improved adaptation over time.
